1) You enter Focus, sometimes with but oftentimes without you even knowing.  This can last a few months. During this time, you are not allowed to transfer internally without VP approval.  Focus is meant to be a formal coaching process to get you to the bar.2) At the end of the Focus period, your manager has to make a decision: did you improve during Focus to somebody that meets the bar for your level?  If yes, you‚Äôre back to normal standing with a healthy dose of stigma associated with you. If no, you enter Pivot (PIP).3) In Pivot, your manager creates a plan with detailed success criteria and milestones.  This plan normally covers about 30-45 days of work and the plan is vetted by your HRBP.4) This plan gets submitted into a system and HR will author the final Pivot document which contains all of the details. This document gets presented to the person in a 1 on 1, sometimes with HR attending.5) This document describes why the person is in Pivot, as well as the Plan to get someone out of Pivot.  They‚Äôre given two options and five days to decide.  If they decide to leave the company now, they will be given severance commensurate to tenure. If they decide to take on the Plan, they forfeit their large severance package in an attempt to keep their job.6) If you don‚Äôt take severance, you do the Plan and can either succeed or fail.  If you succeed (rare), you are back to normal with a really healthy dose of stigma. If you fail, you are potentially offered a fraction of the original severance and your job is terminated.This whole thing is a giant pain in the ass for everyone involved.

At the top level, for unplanned leave (I.e., not something like surgery that has been scheduled well ahead of time), you open an FMLA case through your employer.You then have about three weeks to have scheduled an appointment with medical provider for diagnosis and to have submitted a medical health form from your provider that lists the diagnostics and that your treatment plan includes not working.  (The leave will be denied if it is not supported by a licensed medical provider).There are a few approaches however, that are context based.If you are facing risk of self-harm or immediate consequences, seek urgent care immediately! And just file for FMLA to pause and protect your job while you are working with medical provider... and the diagnostics and paperwork will catch up over the 21 days before it has to be submitted.But most of us who take mental health leave are facing ongoing issue of depression, anxiety, ADHD, autism, past trauma, etc. that is not at an ‚Äúurgent, should not wait‚Äù level.If you are not facing need for urgent care, and there is some doubt or concern whether a psychiatrist or psychologist will (a) provide a diagnosis and (b) state that you are under their care and that you should stop working for a period of time... then you may want to first begin seeing your Primary Care Provider and also begin working with a Psych*. From there, you will know that they will support your leave; and you can more confidently file for FMLA with your employer.  Note: it can still be unscheduled leave (not needing 30 day notice); just less stress knowing you have a provider and they will fill out the forms in a timely manner.* Prioritize finding someone who is right for you for your long term care; but also someone who will support your leave if possible. Often, people do not click with the first Psych they meet with (equally true for therapist as well).Also, many companies provide for short medical or personal leave option ‚Äî maybe 2 to 4 or 6 weeks duration.  It is not job protecting (meaning, your company has discretion on whether to approve it). But, this may also be an option.  A PCP can usually provide medical leave form for this shorter duration leave, but will defer to a Psych specialist for longer FMLA and/or short term disability leave claim.
